definition:
A sequence $x_0,x_1,\dots$ *superconverges to 0* if, when the $x_i$ are
written in base 2, then each number $x_i$ starts with $2^i-1\approx 2^i$
zeroes. For example, the following sequence is superconverging to 0.
$$\begin{array}{clcl}
x_{n+1}&=x_n^2 & (x_n)_{10} & (x_n)_2\\[1.5pt]
x_0 &= & \frac{1}{2} & .1\\[1.5pt]
x_1 &= & \frac{1}{4} & .01\\[1.5pt]
x_2 &= & \frac{1}{16} & .0001\\[1.5pt]
x_3 &= & \frac{1}{256} & .00000001\\[1.5pt]
x_4 &= & \frac{1}{65536} & .0000000000000001
\end{array}$$ In this case it is easy to see that the number of binary
0’s doubles each $x_n$.

A sequence $\{x_i\}$ *superconverges to $x$* if $\{x_i-x\}$
superconverges to 0, and a sequence $\{y_i\}$ is said to be
*superconvergent* if there exists a $y$ to which the sequence
superconverges.
